Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of the circadian clock in Nannochloropsis oceanica
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
Circadian clocks are molecular oscillators with a period of about 24-h. Land plants use the interaction between their circadian clock and light signals to predict daily and seasonal changes. However, little is known on how light quality and the circadian clock reveal time, seasonal, and depth information in the marine ecosystem. The goal of this project is to study the circadian clock of the marine microalga Nannochloropsis oceanica. N. oceanica is currently used as a source of omega-3-fatty acids and due to its high lipid content is being investigated as a potential source of biofuel. N. oceanica belongs to the Stramenopiles a very diverse group of secondary endosymbionts that includes diatoms and plant pathogens such as Phytophtora. Although circadian clocks have been studied in animals, plants, fungi and bacteria, nothing is currently known about the molecular mechanisms regulating the circadian rhythms of Stramenopiles. As part of this project the PI's laboratory will start to identify the molecular components of the circadian clock and characterize the interaction between light signals and circadian rhythms in N. oceanica. These studies will advance our knowledge on the evolution of circadian oscillators, and provide a molecular framework to understand the role of circadian rhythms in phytoplankton physiology. In addition of training graduate students, the PI will provide laboratory research experience for undergraduate students planning to become secondary school teachers. These students will also have the opportunity to develop their own laboratory-teaching units.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Circadian clocks play essential roles in the growth and development of photosynthetic organisms by allowing them to anticipate environmental changes linked to the 24 h light/dark cycles. Although circadian clock components have been identified in green algae and plants, we have a poor understanding about how circadian clocks work in other photosynthetic lineages such as the stramenopiles. Stramenopiles, are a large group of secondary endosymbionts whose plastid originates from a red alga. They include important marine organisms such as diatoms and kelp. We have investigated diurnal and circadian rhythms in the stramenopile algae from the genus Nannochloropsis.Nannochloropsisspecies are small unicellular algae that are currently used as fish food and, due to their elevated lipid content and their easy genetic manipulation, have a biotechnological interest. 

 

We showed that growth, the cell cycle and primary metabolism display tightly synchronized oscillations when Nannochloropsis oceanicacells are grown under light/dark cycles. We generated bioluminescence transgenic lines to be able to track oscillations in gene expression in an automatized manner. Using these lines we demonstrated that these species display damping circadian oscillations under constant light conditions. These rhythms can be entrained by light/dark and temperature cycles, and are temperature compensated, which are key characteristics of circadian clocks. In addition to bioluminescence reporter lines, we also developed a wide range of molecular tools to work with different Nannochloropsisspecies. These tools include vectors for overexpression and subcellular localization, and a gene editing system that allows the generation of transgene-free mutants. These tools will enable future detailed molecular characterization of these organisms. 

 

As part of this project, we trained one graduate student, 5 undergraduate students, and mentored one research technician. Of the undergraduate students, two were part of the Teaching & Research program  and are currently teaching high school science, and two were part of the PlantGenomics@MSU summer program.
